sentence: Wall Street pushed higher on Monday as the Standard & Poor's 500 neared a new record high to extend last week's advances that came amid renewed hopes for trade between the U.S. and China.
The gains were broad, with eight of the 11 S&P sectors in the green.
Materials and energy led, rising about 0.7% each on a stronger day for crude prices.
Utilities and information technology were among the decliners, but despite the tech softness the Nasdaq still ended slightly higher.
Nike ( NKE ) led the Dow Jones Industrial Average higher with a 3% gain after the athletics retailer was upgraded by Piper Jaffray and Susquehanna.
By the close the blue chip measure saw more than half of its components advance, with Merck ( MRK ), Boeing ( BA ) and Home Depot ( HD ) among the best gainers.

With the third straight day of advances, the S&P is now less than 20 points away from its January record high, reclaiming nearly all of the losses it incurred amid a selloff that pushed the measure into correction territory.

"While 2018 has been a volatile year for equities, we continue to expect US large-cap equities to continue their upward trend into 2019," said Chris Haverland, a global asset allocation strategist with Wells Fargo Investment Insitute.
"Yet, the road could be a bumpy one."
Recent gains have come as the U.S. and China are set to begin trade talks amid a spat between the world's biggest economies that has dented sentiment for both consumers and businesses this year.
Investors are also keeping an eye on the economic calendar this week, with minutes from the Federal Reserve's most recent interest rate meeting set to be released.
And Fed Chair Jerome Powell along with other central bank leaders will meet in Jackson Hole, Wyoming later in the week.
Mergers and earnings added to the optimistic tone.
SodaStream International ( SODA ) jumped 9.4% after being bought by PepsiCo (PEP), which was down 0.1%.
Tyson Foods (TSN) rose 1.6% after the company said it would buy chicken nugget maker Keystone Foods.
Estee Lauder (EL) gained 3.4% after earning and revenue came in above the Street's expectations.
